|Title=Knowing how to initiate emergency treatment of an asthma attack in children and adults.
|Description=Emergency oxygen therapy (item 359), systemic corticosteroid therapy and bronchodilators (inhaled beta-mimetics, anticholinergics) and assessing efficacy.

Treatment of exacerbations is based on

o The use of inhaled BDCA (metered-dose aerosol in outpatients, nebulisation in the case of hospitalisation)

o Systemic corticosteroid therapy (0.5 to 1mg/kg/d for 5 days, PO or IV)

o Use of a nebulised anticholinergic (ipratropium) in the event of severe exacerbation.

o Oxygen therapy and/or ventilatory assistance should be discussed in the event of severe exacerbation (in intensive care).

question.question: Which of the following is the primary treatment for initiating emergency treatment of an asthma attack in children and adults?
question.option_a: Administering oral antihistamines to reduce inflammation
question.option_b: Using systemic corticosteroid therapy at a dose of 0.5 to 1mg/kg/d for 5 days, PO or IV
question.option_c: Providing inhaled bronchodilators and anticholinergics through a nebulizer
question.option_d: Giving intravenous antibiotics to prevent secondary infections
